Breadth-First.Explanation: Initial open-ended listing of visual clues and possible stations without settling on a hypothesis (clue collection).
Divergent consideration of multiple regions (Spain, Switzerland, Paris) based on various design features (hypothesis generation).
Further broad speculation across different countries and lines (Switzerland, Marseille, Barcelona, RER E) driven by feature mismatches (hypothesis generation).

Depth-First.Explanation: Focused analysis of specific train stock and livery to propose a particular station hypothesis for verification.
Depth-First.KeyElement: MI 09/RER E underground station like Magenta

Depth-First.Explanation: Targeted inspection of platform layout, lettered signage, and station finishes to test the Magenta hypothesis.
Depth-First.KeyElement: Island platform G with wooden slats and concrete arches

Depth-First.Explanation: Close reading of the letter “G” signage function (exit vs. platform) to confirm or refute the station identity.
Depth-First.KeyElement: Exit‐letter G indicating Place Carpeaux access

Depth-First.Explanation: Convergent derivation of a new candidate (La Défense Grande Arche) based on architectural style, signage conventions, and designer attribution.
Depth-First.KeyElement: Jean-Marie Duthilleul wood slats and Parisian exit lettering system

Depth-First.Explanation: Final affirmation of the station’s identity based on cumulative evidence.
Depth-First.KeyElement: La Défense – Grande Arche RER E station

Breadth-Depth Switch.Explanation: Attention shifted from listing many location options to verifying a specific station hypothesis via detailed coach and livery analysis.
